text: Does anyone use a specific wordpress plugin other than Yoast? We currently use the free version of Yoast and I’m just curious if the paid version is worth it or if there are any others worth looking into.

elements.text: Does anyone use a specific wordpress plugin other than Yoast? We currently use the free version of Yoast and I’m just curious if the paid version is worth it or if there are any others worth looking into.

text: <@UUXMCJQ15> has thoughts on "SEO" plugins

elements.text: has thoughts on "SEO" plugins

text: Depends on what you use it for. I find that the "content rating" feature (XX/100 score, for example) on nearly all of these plugins has little bearing on whether or not the piece goes on to be successful. My company uses RankMath, but we primarily use it for broader SEO assistance/optimization and metadata, as well as the Schema feature.

elements.text: Depends on what you use it for. I find that the "content rating" feature (XX/100 score, for example) on nearly all of these plugins has little bearing on whether or not the piece goes on to be successful. My company uses RankMath, but we primarily use it for broader SEO assistance/optimization and metadata, as well as the Schema feature.

text:
Definitely wouldn't pay for it (ever).

<https://seofortherestofus.org/seo/plugins/>

attachments.fallback: SEO for the Rest of Us - Learn SEO Fast (Seriously): Are "SEO Plugins" Killing Your Website? - SEO for the Rest of Us
attachments.text: The two most popular "SEO" plugins do absolutely nothing to increase your rank in search. Here's why, plus how they might be hurting you.
attachments.title: Are "SEO Plugins" Killing Your Website? - SEO for the Rest of Us
attachments.service_name: SEO for the Rest of Us - Learn SEO Fast (Seriously)

elements.text: Definitely wouldn't pay for it (ever).

text:
Truth is, those plugins can help with website things, but they don't touch any of the 3 things that actually drive rankings (and thus, traffic):

1. Search intent
2. Matching that intent with content
3. Backlinks from other sites to that page

elements.text: Truth is, those plugins can help with website things, but they don't touch any of the 3 things that actually drive rankings (and thus, traffic):
Search intent
Matching that intent with content
Backlinks from other sites to that page

text:
To answer <@U03286FJU1W>’s question of how SEO changed my life, I’m having a strange and great thing happen where _*at least once a day for 8 weeks now*_, I see a sale come through for my Notability digital planner product.

Whenever I reach out to ask someone how they found me, they say it’s because my site ranks at the top for Notability digital planning.

This is backed by my deep-dive into Google Analytics, showing the amount of traffic that comes in directly through those couple of blog posts.

Now it’s time for me to double-down on these efforts, create more content, and create more relevant products!

(I feel like it’s also important to note that my site is on Squarespace… and when I wrote the post I had little-to-no knowledge of SEO best-practices.)

text: Hey all! What techniques/strategies have you all found to be the most helpful when it comes to reducing the bounce rate for certain pages/content?

elements.text: Hey all! What techniques/strategies have you all found to be the most helpful when it comes to reducing the bounce rate for certain pages/content?

text:
I wouldn’t focus on reducing the bounce rate, but instead focus on increasing the conversion rate. 

Trying to reduce the bounce rate almost always encourages using whatever tactic possible to keep people reading the page longer, but the real goal should be to get people what they need and let them leave as quickly as possible. 

If we can give them a reason to continue engaging with us, such as giving us their email address, then let’s definitely do that :+1:

elements.text:
I wouldn’t focus on reducing the bounce rate, but instead focus on increasing the conversion rate. 

Trying to reduce the bounce rate almost always encourages using whatever tactic possible to keep people reading the page longer, but the real goal should be to get people what they need and let them leave as quickly as possible. 

If we can give them a reason to continue engaging with us, such as giving us their email address, then let’s definitely do that

text: Hi Brendan! That's a good point and it's something I was curious about. For example, if a blog has the answer to a question in the first paragraph, and let's say the bounce rate is 100% for that page, would people who read the first couple paragraphs and exit still be counted as bounces?

elements.text: Hi Brendan! That's a good point and it's something I was curious about. For example, if a blog has the answer to a question in the first paragraph, and let's say the bounce rate is 100% for that page, would people who read the first couple paragraphs and exit still be counted as bounces?

text:
<@U02TDTEHQKA> Yep. Any time a single event occurs on a page, it counts as a bounce. The page loading is the first event. You can modify this how you see fit so long as everyone is in alignment on what constitutes a “bounce” to your organization.

For example, for us, we have different criteria for different page types. A blog post fires an event if the reader is engaged (e.g. spends x time on page and scrolls y percent down the page)—causing that to not count as a bounce.

However, on sales pages, we don’t count those same criteria but instead treat it as a bounce if a conversion event doesn’t occur (e.g. call booked).

Setting all this up usually isn’t worth the effort though—and, like <@UUXMCJQ15> said, you’re usually better off ignoring bounce rate and focusing on version rate.

elements.text:
Yep. Any time a single event occurs on a page, it counts as a bounce. The page loading is the first event. You can modify this how you see fit so long as everyone is in alignment on what constitutes a “bounce” to your organization.

For example, for us, we have different criteria for different page types. A blog post fires an event if the reader is engaged (e.g. spends x time on page and scrolls y percent down the page)—causing that to not count as a bounce.

However, on sales pages, we don’t count those same criteria but instead treat it as a bounce if a conversion event doesn’t occur (e.g. call booked).

Setting all this up usually isn’t worth the effort though—and, like
said, you’re usually better off ignoring bounce rate and focusing on version rate.

text:
Got a very specific question for anyone who's done technical SEO analysis for brands that use study links from NIH. Have you ever run across <https://d.pr/i/ndM2gj|an error like this> in ScreamingFrog? And if so, did you ever find out _why_?

Here's what I'm dealing with: ScreamingFrog flagged these study links as 301s on a CBD site I'm auditing. However, the link they redirect _to_ is a <https://misuse.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/error/abuse.shtml|misuse/abuse page on NIH's site> that says they blocked the link due to misuse of the link.

However, when I go to the client's site and click the link on the page, I'm taken to the study as normal.

I audit health-related sites often, and I've never seen study links do this in a ScreamingFrog report. And it's not just one — it's ALL of the study links I've seen from the NIH site so far.

My tendency right now is to assume it's okay (mostly because the links work when clicked in a live environment), but I wanted to ask if this very strange occurrence was familiar to anyone else. Any insight would be much appreciated!
